DataElement.preferredName: Person Malignant Neoplasm Recurrent Or Refractory Disease Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria Code Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A response to questions which are necessary to allow a patient to participate in a clinical study that address the return of disease, or no response to cancer treatment, as outlined the clinical trial protocol.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Person Malignant Neoplasm Recurrent Disease Or Refractory Disease Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A human being._A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._The return of a disease after a period of remission._An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._A disease that resists treatment._Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Property.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Recurrent Disease Or Refractory Disease Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria
Property.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.:The return of a disease after a period of remission.:An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.:A disease that resists treatment.:Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
The return of a disease after a period of remission.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Yes No Not Applicable Code Indicator

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.
The non-affirmative response to a question.
Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Created to support Theradex design of CRFs for NCI CCR trials

ReferenceDocuments.name: If patient has BCL6+DLBCL, ha
ReferenceDocuments.description: If patient has BCL6+DLBCL, has disease relapsed and or is refractory to prior therapy, which must have included an anthracycline, if not contraindicated?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have disease that has relapsed after or is refractory to at least 2 lines of standard therapy?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have relapsed and/or refractory myeloma and is experiencing disease relapse?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 3
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have relapsed or refractory AML, defined as, RELAPSED: greater than or equal to 5% bone marrow blasts by morphology, reappearance of MRD above 0.1% by flow cytometry, reappearance of peripheral blood blasts, or development of extramedullary leukemia after one or more prior lines of therapy.  Consolidation regimens, including autologous and allogeneic HCT, do not count as a separate prior line of therapy, (e.g., 7+3 followed by cytarabine consolidation followed by allogeneic HCT would be considered one prior line of therapy) or REFRACTORY:  no CR or CRi after two courses of induction therapy (e.g. therapy with the intent to induce remission)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex- 4
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have RRMM without t(11;14), confirmed by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 5
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have relapsed AML (greater than or equal to 5% bone marrow blasts by morphology, reappearance of peripheral blood blasts, or development of extramedullary leukemia after achieving prior CR or CRi)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 6
ReferenceDocuments.description: If patient is in the Dose expansion phase, does patient have relapsed or refractory transformed lymphoma or GCB-DLBCL as defined by Hans criteria?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 7
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have transformed NLPHL or the treating physician has concerns of an occult transformation or that the patient needs cytotoxic therapy?
